mn37:0.2.eng: The Shorter Discourse on the Ending of Craving

mn37:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati pubbārāme migāramātupāsāde.
mn37:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in the stilt longhouse of Migāra’s mother in the Eastern Monastery.

mn37:2.1.pli: Atha kho sakko devānamindo yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsi. Ekamantaṃ ṭhito kho sakko devānamindo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
mn37:2.1.eng: And then Sakka, lord of gods, went up to the Buddha, bowed, stood to one side, and said to him:
mn37:2.1.comm: A long account of Sakka’s first meeting with the Buddha and conversion is found at DN 21. There he is said to have attained stream-entry, and so is destined for full awakening. Yet even a stream-enterer may slow their progress by negligence (Snp 2.1:9.3) | Sakka’s epithet “lord of gods” (devānamindo) evokes his more familiar Sanskrit name, Indra.

mn37:2.2.pli: “kittāvatā nu kho, bhante, bhikkhu saṅkhittena taṇhāsaṅkhayavimutto hoti accantaniṭṭho accantayogakkhemī accantabrahmacārī accantapariyosāno seṭṭho devamanussānan”ti?
mn37:2.2.eng: “Sir, how do you briefly define a mendicant who is freed through the ending of craving, who has reached the ultimate end, the ultimate sanctuary from the yoke, the ultimate spiritual life, the ultimate goal, and is best among gods and humans?”
mn37:2.2.comm: This question directly follows on from the final question at DN 21:2.6.9, where Sakka asks whether all ascetics and brahmins have reached the ultimate goal. Here he delves deeper into what that means. | Now that he is a confirmed Buddhist, Sakka switches from “ascetics and brahmins” to “mendicants”. | This passage has an exact parallel at AN 7.61:12.2, and a variation at SN 35:80.1.

mn37:3.1.eng: “lord of gods, take a mendicant who has heard:

mn37:3.2.comm: The Buddha is calling back to the previous conversation, where immediately before asking about the ultimate goal, Sakka had asked why all ascetics did not share a common doctrine (DN 21:2.6.6). The Buddha answered that, though the world has many and diverse elements, ascetics tend to fixate on one aspect and “insist” it is the only truth.

mn37:3.3.eng: When a mendicant has heard that

mn37:3.5.pli: So sabbaṃ dhammaṃ abhijānāti; sabbaṃ dhammaṃ abhiññāya sabbaṃ dhammaṃ parijānāti; sabbaṃ dhammaṃ pariññāya yaṃ kiñci vedanaṃ vedeti—
mn37:3.5.eng: they directly know all things. Directly knowing all things, they completely understand all things. Completely understanding all things, when they experience any kind of feeling—pleasant, unpleasant, or neutral—
mn37:3.5.comm: One who has learned the theory of non-attachment is still liable to become attached, so they apply their knowledge to experiential insight into “all things”. Normally “complete understanding” (pariññā) indicates arahantship, but here it reinforces “direct knowledge” (abhiññā) as the wisdom of stream-entry. However, the force of attachment is so deeply ingrained that even a stream-enterer, such as Sakka, with both theoretical and experiential wisdom is still not free. So they must then continue to meditate on the feelings in order to let go fully.

mn37:3.6.pli: sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā, so tāsu vedanāsu aniccānupassī viharati, virāgānupassī viharati, nirodhānupassī viharati, paṭinissaggānupassī viharati.
mn37:3.6.eng: they meditate observing impermanence, dispassion, cessation, and letting go in those feelings.

mn37:3.7.pli: So tāsu vedanāsu aniccānupassī viharanto, virāgānupassī viharanto, nirodhānupassī viharanto, paṭinissaggānupassī viharanto na kiñci loke upādiyati.
mn37:3.7.eng: Meditating in this way, they don’t grasp at anything in the world.

mn37:3.8.pli: Anupādiyaṃ na paritassati, aparitassaṃ paccattaññeva parinibbāyati:
mn37:3.8.eng: Not grasping, they’re not anxious. Not being anxious, they personally become extinguished.

mn37:3.9.pli: ‘khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ, nāparaṃ itthattāyā’ti pajānāti.
mn37:3.9.eng: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is nothing further for this place.’

mn37:3.10.pli: Ettāvatā kho, devānaminda, bhikkhu saṅkhittena taṇhāsaṅkhayavimutto hoti accantaniṭṭho accantayogakkhemī accantabrahmacārī accantapariyosāno seṭṭho devamanussānan”ti.
mn37:3.10.eng: That’s how I briefly define a mendicant who is freed through the ending of craving, who has reached the ultimate end, the ultimate sanctuary from the yoke, the ultimate spiritual life, the ultimate goal, and is best among gods and humans.”

mn37:4.1.pli: Atha kho sakko devānamindo bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinanditvā anumoditvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṃ katvā tatthevantaradhāyi.
mn37:4.1.eng: Then Sakka, lord of gods, having approved and agreed with what the Buddha said, bowed and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right, before vanishing right there.

mn37:5.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmā mahāmoggallāno bhagavato avidūre nisinno hoti.
mn37:5.1.eng: Now at that time Venerable Mahāmoggallāna was sitting not far from the Buddha.

mn37:5.3.pli: “kiṃ nu kho so yakkho bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhisamecca anumodi udāhu no;
mn37:5.3.eng: “Did that spirit comprehend what the Buddha said when he agreed with him, or not?
mn37:5.3.comm: Moggallāna refers to Sakka as a “spirit” (yakkha).

mn37:5.5.pli: yadi vā so yakkho bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhisamecca anumodi yadi vā no”ti?

mn37:6.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā mahāmoggallāno—seyyathāpi nāma balavā puriso samiñjitaṃ vā bāhaṃ pasāreyya, pasāritaṃ vā bāhaṃ samiñjeyya; evameva—pubbārāme migāramātupāsāde antarahito devesu tāvatiṃsesu pāturahosi.
mn37:6.1.eng: And then Venerable Mahāmoggallāna, as easily as a strong person would extend or contract their arm, vanished from the Eastern Monastery and reappeared among the gods of the thirty-three.
mn37:6.1.comm: Moggallāna was the foremost in psychic powers.

mn37:7.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena sakko devānamindo ekapuṇḍarīke uyyāne dibbehi pañcahi tūriyasatehi samappito samaṅgībhūto paricāreti.
mn37:7.1.eng: Now at that time Sakka was amusing himself in the Single Lotus Park, supplied and provided with a heavenly orchestra.
mn37:7.1.comm: A pañcaṅgikatūriya is a band of five musicians, a “quintet”. Here it is amplified a hundredfold, so I translate “orchestra”. | “Single lotus” (ekapuṇḍarīka) appears as an auspicious epithet in a prayer for wealth at Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 6.3.6.

mn37:7.2.pli: Addasā kho sakko devānamindo āyasmantaṃ mahāmoggallānaṃ dūratova āgacchantaṃ.
mn37:7.2.eng: Seeing Mahāmoggallāna coming off in the distance,

mn37:7.3.pli: Disvāna tāni dibbāni pañca tūriyasatāni paṭippaṇāmetvā yenāyasmā mahāmoggallāno tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṃ mahāmoggallānaṃ etadavoca:
mn37:7.3.eng: he waved off the orchestra, approached Mahāmoggallāna, and said,
mn37:7.3.comm: The Pali paṭippaṇāmeti, literally “bend back”, occurs also in the “fending off” of Lady Luck at MN 49:5.9. Sometimes it has a metaphorical meaning (AN 6.42:10.2), but there it seems to indicate a physical movement with a staff, a waving gesture to ward off an ill omen. Normally the verb paṇamati means to “bow”, so it too has a physical meaning, even though the connotation is opposite. It is used by the Buddha in “dismissing” a badly behaved Saṅgha (MN 67:5.1). Perhaps there, as here, it also retains a physical aspect, to “wave off”.

mn37:7.4.pli: “ehi kho, mārisa moggallāna, svāgataṃ, mārisa moggallāna.
mn37:7.4.eng: “Come, my good Moggallāna! Welcome, good fellow!

mn37:7.5.pli: Cirassaṃ kho, mārisa moggallāna, imaṃ pariyāyaṃ akāsi yadidaṃ idhāgamanāya.
mn37:7.5.eng: It’s been a long time since you took the opportunity to come here.

mn37:7.6.eng: Sit, my good Moggallāna, this seat is for you.”

mn37:7.7.pli: Nisīdi kho āyasmā mahāmoggallāno paññatte āsane.
mn37:7.7.eng: Mahāmoggallāna sat down on the seat spread out,

mn37:7.8.pli: Sakkopi kho devānamindo aññataraṃ nīcaṃ āsanaṃ gahetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi.
mn37:7.8.eng: while Sakka took a low seat and sat to one side.

mn37:7.9.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho sakkaṃ devānamindaṃ āyasmā mahāmoggallāno etadavoca:

mn37:8.1.pli: “yathā kathaṃ pana kho, kosiya, bhagavā saṅkhittena taṇhāsaṅkhayavimuttiṃ abhāsi?
mn37:8.1.eng: “Kosiya, how did the Buddha briefly explain freedom through the ending of craving?
mn37:8.1.comm: Moggallāna refers to Sakka as “Kosiya” rather than the Buddha’s “lord of gods”. Old gods like Sakka tend to accrue many names. The word kosiya is explained by the commentaries as “owl”, which, if correct, would have been the totem for a clan of that name. It is, however, a patronymic: Rig Veda 1.10.11 has indra kauśika which means “Indra, son of Kuśika (or Kuśa)”. Kuśa grass is critical to the performance of Vedic rites, and the label probably initially implied “Brahmanized”, i.e. a king whose reign was authorized according to Vedic ritual. Kosiya is said to be a low class family name (Bu Pc 2:2.1.18).

mn37:8.2.pli: Sādhu mayampi etissā kathāya bhāgino assāma savanāyā”ti.
mn37:8.2.eng: Please share this talk with me so that I can also get to hear it.”

mn37:8.3.eng: “My good Moggallāna, I have many duties, and much to do,

mn37:8.4.pli: appeva sakena karaṇīyena, api ca devānaṃyeva tāvatiṃsānaṃ karaṇīyena.
mn37:8.4.eng: not only for myself, but also for the gods of the thirty-three.

mn37:8.5.pli: Api ca, mārisa moggallāna, sussutaṃyeva hoti suggahitaṃ sumanasikataṃ sūpadhāritaṃ, yaṃ no khippameva antaradhāyati.
mn37:8.5.eng: Still, what is properly heard, learned, attended, and memorized does not vanish all of a sudden.
mn37:8.5.comm: The commentary reads no as a personal pronoun (amhākaṁ) which results in the sense, “Even what I have well remembered quickly vanishes.” This is logically dubious—how is it “properly learned” if it quickly vanishes?—and contradicted below where Sakka shows that he does in fact remember perfectly well (MN 37:12.5). Instead, read no as negative particle. Sakka is brushing Moggallāna off by insisting he has learned his lesson, without taking the trouble to actually remember it.

mn37:8.6.pli: Bhūtapubbaṃ, mārisa moggallāna, devāsurasaṅgāmo samupabyūḷho ahosi.
mn37:8.6.eng: Once upon a time, a battle was fought between the gods and the titans.
mn37:8.6.comm: He tries to distract Moggallāna with talk of his glory days, rehashing vendettas that were old even in the Vedas.

mn37:8.7.pli: Tasmiṃ kho pana, mārisa moggallāna, saṅgāme devā jiniṃsu, asurā parājiniṃsu.
mn37:8.7.eng: In that battle the gods won and the titans lost.

mn37:8.8.pli: So kho ahaṃ, mārisa moggallāna, taṃ saṅgāmaṃ abhivijinitvā vijitasaṅgāmo tato paṭinivattitvā vejayantaṃ nāma pāsādaṃ māpesiṃ.
mn37:8.8.eng: When I returned from that battle as a conqueror, I created the Palace of Victory.

mn37:8.9.pli: Vejayantassa kho, mārisa moggallāna, pāsādassa ekasataṃ niyyūhaṃ.
mn37:8.9.eng: The Palace of Victory has a hundred towers.

mn37:8.10.eng: Each tower has seven hundred chambers.

mn37:8.13.pli: Iccheyyāsi no tvaṃ, mārisa moggallāna, vejayantassa pāsādassa rāmaṇeyyakaṃ daṭṭhun”ti?
mn37:8.13.eng: Would you like to see the lovely Palace of Victory?”

mn37:9.1.pli: Atha kho sakko ca devānamindo vessavaṇo ca mahārājā āyasmantaṃ mahāmoggallānaṃ purakkhatvā yena vejayanto pāsādo tenupasaṅkamiṃsu.
mn37:9.1.eng: Then, putting Venerable Mahāmoggallāna in front, Sakka, lord of gods, and Vessavaṇa, the Great King, went to the Palace of Victory.
mn37:9.1.comm: Also known as Kuvera (DN 20:9.31, Snp 2.14:6.1), the name Vessavaṇa means “Son of the Renowned” from his father Viśrava, although DN 32:7.40 explains it as from the name of his city. He is one of the four great kings and guards the northern quarter.

mn37:9.2.pli: Addasaṃsu kho sakkassa devānamindassa paricārikāyo āyasmantaṃ mahāmoggallānaṃ dūratova āgacchantaṃ;
mn37:9.2.eng: When they saw Moggallāna coming off in the distance, Sakka’s maids,

mn37:9.3.pli: disvā ottappamānā hirīyamānā sakaṃ sakaṃ ovarakaṃ pavisiṃsu.
mn37:9.3.eng: being discreet and prudent, each went to her own bedroom.
mn37:9.3.comm: The maids are described as possessing the cardinal virtues of hiri (conscience, discretion) and otappa (prudence), the “guardians of the world” and the foundations of moral integrity. Former translators have rendered this as if the maids were “embarrassed and ashamed”, but this is unwarranted. The maids were born in this realm as the result of their good kamma in past lives and are simply residing there in their own home. Unlike Sakka, who neglected his lesson and then tried to distract attention when reminded of it, they have nothing to be ashamed of.

mn37:10.1.pli: Seyyathāpi nāma suṇisā sasuraṃ disvā ottappati hirīyati;
mn37:10.1.eng: They were just like a daughter-in-law who is discreet and prudent when they see their father-in-law.

mn37:10.2.pli: evameva sakkassa devānamindassa paricārikāyo āyasmantaṃ mahāmoggallānaṃ disvā ottappamānā hirīyamānā sakaṃ sakaṃ ovarakaṃ pavisiṃsu.

mn37:10.3.pli: Atha kho sakko ca devānamindo vessavaṇo ca mahārājā āyasmantaṃ mahāmoggallānaṃ vejayante pāsāde anucaṅkamāpenti anuvicarāpenti:
mn37:10.3.eng: Then Sakka and Vessavaṇa encouraged Moggallāna to wander and explore the palace, saying,
mn37:10.3.comm: This is a good example of (anu)-vicāra in the sense of “explore”.

mn37:10.4.pli: “idampi, mārisa moggallāna, passa vejayantassa pāsādassa rāmaṇeyyakaṃ;
mn37:10.4.eng: “See, in the palace, my good Moggallāna, this lovely thing!

mn37:10.5.pli: idampi, mārisa moggallāna, passa vejayantassa pāsādassa rāmaṇeyyakan”ti.
mn37:10.5.comm: The gods are pointing out various pretty features in the palace.

mn37:10.6.pli: “Sobhati idaṃ āyasmato kosiyassa, yathā taṃ pubbe katapuññassa.
mn37:10.6.eng: “That looks beautiful for the venerable Kosiya, as befits one who has made merit in the past.
mn37:10.6.comm: After Sakka’s disappointing response, Moggallāna is trying to say something nice. At the same time, he subtly implies the difference between his past merit and present negligence.

mn37:10.7.eng: Humans, when they see something lovely, also say:

mn37:10.8.eng: ‘It looks beautiful enough for the gods of the thirty-three!’

mn37:10.9.pli: Tayidaṃ āyasmato kosiyassa sobhati, yathā taṃ pubbe katapuññassā”ti.
mn37:10.9.eng: That looks beautiful for the venerable Kosiya, as befits one who has made merit in the past.”

mn37:11.3.eng: Why don’t I stir up a sense of urgency in him?”

mn37:11.4.pli: Atha kho āyasmā mahāmoggallāno tathārūpaṃ iddhābhisaṅkhāraṃ abhisaṅkhāsi yathā vejayantaṃ pāsādaṃ pādaṅguṭṭhakena saṅkampesi sampakampesi sampavedhesi.
mn37:11.4.eng: Then Moggallāna used his psychic power to make the Palace of Victory shake and rock and tremble with his big toe.
mn37:11.4.comm: Referred to at Thag 20.1:55.1. Moggallāna displayed a similar wonder at SN 51.14:3.1, also a means of last resort in the face of negligence.

mn37:11.5.pli: Atha kho sakko ca devānamindo, vessavaṇo ca mahārājā, devā ca tāvatiṃsā acchariyabbhutacittajātā ahesuṃ:
mn37:11.5.eng: Then Sakka, Vessavaṇa, and the gods of the thirty-three, their minds full of wonder and amazement, thought,

mn37:11.7.pli: Samaṇassa mahiddhikatā mahānubhāvatā, yatra hi nāma dibbabhavanaṃ pādaṅguṭṭhakena saṅkampessati sampakampessati sampavedhessatī”ti.
mn37:11.7.eng: The ascetic has such power and might that he makes the god’s home shake and rock and tremble with his big toe!”

mn37:12.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā mahāmoggallāno sakkaṃ devānamindaṃ saṃviggaṃ lomahaṭṭhajātaṃ viditvā sakkaṃ devānamindaṃ etadavoca:
mn37:12.1.eng: Knowing that Sakka was shocked and awestruck, Moggallāna said to him,

mn37:12.2.pli: “yathā kathaṃ pana kho, kosiya, bhagavā saṅkhittena taṇhāsaṅkhayavimuttiṃ abhāsi?
mn37:12.2.eng: “Kosiya, how did the Buddha briefly explain freedom through the ending of craving?

mn37:12.3.pli: Sādhu mayampi etissā kathāya bhāgino assāma savanāyā”ti.
mn37:12.3.eng: Please share this talk with me so that I can also get to hear it.”

mn37:12.4.pli: “Idhāhaṃ, mārisa moggallāna, yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃ; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsiṃ. Ekamantaṃ ṭhito kho ahaṃ, mārisa moggallāna, bhagavantaṃ etadavocaṃ:
mn37:12.4.eng: “My dear Moggallāna, I approached the Buddha, bowed, stood to one side, and said to him,

mn37:12.5.pli: ‘kittāvatā nu kho, bhante, bhikkhu saṅkhittena taṇhāsaṅkhayavimutto hoti accantaniṭṭho accantayogakkhemī accantabrahmacārī accantapariyosāno seṭṭho devamanussānan’ti?
mn37:12.5.eng: ‘Sir, how do you briefly define a mendicant who is freed with the ending of craving, who has reached the ultimate end, the ultimate sanctuary from the yoke, the ultimate spiritual life, the ultimate goal, and is best among gods and humans?’

mn37:13.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, mārisa moggallāna, bhagavā maṃ etadavoca:
mn37:13.1.eng: When I had spoken the Buddha said to me:

mn37:13.2.eng: ‘lord of gods, it’s when a mendicant has heard:

mn37:13.4.eng: When a mendicant has heard that

mn37:13.6.pli: So sabbaṃ dhammaṃ abhijānāti, sabbaṃ dhammaṃ abhiññāya sabbaṃ dhammaṃ parijānāti, sabbaṃ dhammaṃ pariññāya yaṃ kiñci vedanaṃ vedeti sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā.
mn37:13.6.eng: they directly know all things. Directly knowing all things, they completely understand all things. Having completely understood all things, when they experience any kind of feeling—pleasant, unpleasant, or neutral—

mn37:13.7.pli: So tāsu vedanāsu aniccānupassī viharati, virāgānupassī viharati, nirodhānupassī viharati, paṭinissaggānupassī viharati.
mn37:13.7.eng: they meditate observing impermanence, dispassion, cessation, and letting go in those feelings.

mn37:13.8.pli: So tāsu vedanāsu aniccānupassī viharanto, virāgānupassī viharanto, nirodhānupassī viharanto, paṭinissaggānupassī viharanto na kiñci loke upādiyati,
mn37:13.8.eng: Meditating in this way, they don’t grasp at anything in the world.

mn37:13.9.pli: anupādiyaṃ na paritassati, aparitassaṃ paccattaññeva parinibbāyati:
mn37:13.9.eng: Not grasping, they’re not anxious. Not being anxious, they personally become extinguished.

mn37:13.10.pli: “khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ, nāparaṃ itthattāyā”ti pajānāti.
mn37:13.10.eng: They understand: “Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is nothing further for this place.”

mn37:13.11.pli: Ettāvatā kho, devānaminda, bhikkhu saṅkhittena taṇhāsaṅkhayavimutto hoti accantaniṭṭho accantayogakkhemī accantabrahmacārī accantapariyosāno seṭṭho devamanussānan’ti.
mn37:13.11.eng: That’s how I briefly define a mendicant who is freed through the ending of craving, who has reached the ultimate end, the ultimate sanctuary from the yoke, the ultimate spiritual life, the ultimate goal, and is best among gods and humans.’

mn37:13.12.pli: Evaṃ kho me, mārisa moggallāna, bhagavā saṅkhittena taṇhāsaṅkhayavimuttiṃ abhāsī”ti.
mn37:13.12.eng: That’s how the Buddha briefly explained freedom through the ending of craving to me.”

mn37:14.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā mahāmoggallāno sakkassa devānamindassa bhāsitaṃ abhinanditvā anumoditvā—seyyathāpi nāma balavā puriso samiñjitaṃ vā bāhaṃ pasāreyya, pasāritaṃ vā bāhaṃ samiñjeyya; evameva—devesu tāvatiṃsesu antarahito pubbārāme migāramātupāsāde pāturahosi.
mn37:14.1.eng: Moggallāna approved and agreed with what Sakka said. As easily as a strong person would extend or contract their arm, he vanished from among the gods of the thirty-three and reappeared in the Eastern Monastery.

mn37:14.2.pli: Atha kho sakkassa devānamindassa paricārikāyo acirapakkante āyasmante mahāmoggallāne sakkaṃ devānamindaṃ etadavocuṃ:
mn37:14.2.eng: Soon after Moggallāna left, Sakka’s maids said to him,

mn37:14.3.pli: “eso nu te, mārisa, so bhagavā satthā”ti?
mn37:14.3.eng: “Good fellow, was that the Blessed One, your Teacher?”

mn37:14.4.pli: “Na kho me, mārisa, so bhagavā satthā.

mn37:14.5.eng: That was my spiritual companion Venerable Mahāmoggallāna.”
mn37:14.5.comm: “Spiritual companion” (sabrahmacārī) normally refers to a fellow monastic, but here it alludes to the fact that both of them have seen the Dhamma.

mn37:14.6.eng: “You’re fortunate, good fellow, so very fortunate,

mn37:14.7.eng: to have a spiritual companion of such power and might!

mn37:14.8.pli: Aho nūna te so bhagavā satthā”ti.
mn37:14.8.eng: We can’t believe that’s not the Blessed One, your Teacher!”

mn37:15.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā mahāmoggallāno yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā mahāmoggallāno bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
mn37:15.1.eng: Then Mahāmoggallāna went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him,

mn37:15.2.pli: “abhijānāti no, bhante, bhagavā ahu ñātaññatarassa mahesakkhassa yakkhassa saṅkhittena taṇhāsaṅkhayavimuttiṃ bhāsitā”ti?
mn37:15.2.eng: “Sir, do you recall briefly explaining freedom through the ending of craving to a certain well-known and illustrious spirit?”
mn37:15.2.comm: It is unclear why Moggallāna asked for a repetition of the teaching at which he was present. One might have expected that he would report to the Buddha the events at Sakka’s palace.

mn37:15.3.pli: “Abhijānāmahaṃ, moggallāna, idha sakko devānamindo yenāhaṃ tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā maṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsi. Ekamantaṃ ṭhito kho, moggallāna, sakko devānamindo maṃ etadavoca:
mn37:15.3.eng: “I do, Moggallāna.” And the Buddha retold all that happened when Sakka came to visit him, adding:

mn37:15.4.pli: ‘kittāvatā nu kho, bhante, bhikkhu saṅkhittena taṇhāsaṅkhayavimutto hoti accantaniṭṭho accantayogakkhemī accantabrahmacārī accantapariyosāno seṭṭho devamanussānan’ti.

mn37:15.5.pli: Evaṃ vutte, ahaṃ, moggallāna, sakkaṃ devānamindaṃ etadavocaṃ

mn37:15.8.pli: Evaṃ cetaṃ, devānaminda, bhikkhuno sutaṃ hoti

mn37:15.10.pli: So sabbaṃ dhammaṃ abhijānāti, sabbaṃ dhammaṃ abhiññāya sabbaṃ dhammaṃ parijānāti, sabbaṃ dhammaṃ pariññāya yaṃ kiñci vedanaṃ vedeti sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā.

mn37:15.11.pli: So tāsu vedanāsu aniccānupassī viharati, virāgānupassī viharati, nirodhānupassī viharati, paṭinissaggānupassī viharati.

mn37:15.12.pli: So tāsu vedanāsu aniccānupassī viharanto, virāgānupassī viharanto, nirodhānupassī viharanto,

mn37:15.13.pli: paṭinissaggānupassī viharanto na kiñci loke upādiyati,

mn37:15.14.pli: anupādiyaṃ na paritassati, aparitassaṃ paccattaññeva parinibbāyati:

mn37:15.15.pli: “khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ, nāparaṃ itthattāyā”ti pajānāti.

mn37:15.16.pli: Ettāvatā kho, devānaminda, bhikkhu saṅkhittena taṇhāsaṅkhayavimutto hoti accantaniṭṭho accantayogakkhemī accantabrahmacārī accantapariyosāno seṭṭho devamanussānan’ti.

mn37:15.17.pli: Evaṃ kho ahaṃ, moggallāna, abhijānāmi sakkassa devānamindassa saṅkhittena taṇhāsaṅkhayavimuttiṃ bhāsitā”ti.
mn37:15.17.eng: “That’s how I recall briefly explaining freedom through the ending of craving to Sakka, lord of gods.”

mn37:15.18.eng: That is what the Buddha said.

mn37:15.19.pli: Attamano āyasmā mahāmoggallāno bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinandīti.
mn37:15.19.eng: Satisfied, Venerable Mahāmoggallāna approved what the Buddha said.
